File.Title: Afferent Connections of the Lateral Agranular Field of the Rat Motor Cortex
File.Authors: JOHN P. DONOGHUE AND CAROL PARHAM

Abstract.S: Retrograde axonal transport techniques were used to identify the afferent connections of the lateral agranular field (AGl) of the rat frontal cortex.
This cytoarchitectonically distinct cortical field forms the bulk of the primary motor cortex (MI) as defined by intracortical microstimulation studies (Donoghue and Wise, '82).
Following injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) or wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to HRP into AGI, retrogradely labeled cells are found in the forebrain, thalamus, and brainstem.

Within the cerebral cortex labeled neurons are mainly present in the first somatic sensory area (SI), the second somatic sensory area (SII), and the medial agranular field, which lies medial and rostral to AGl.
In SI, labeled cells are found primarily in a cytoarchitecturally distinct region called the dysgranular field of SI.
Labeled neurons are present in layers I1 and 111, Va, and the deepest part of layer VI in this field and in SII.
Labeled cells are also present in layers Va and VI of the densely granular field of SI, which is the part of SI that is strongly activated by cutaneous inputs.
Commissural inputs to AG1 arise from layers 11-VI of the contralateral AG1 and thalamic inputs arise from the ventrolateral, ventromedial, posterior medial, and central lateral nuclei.
Additional afferent fibers originate from neurons in the basal forebrain, the ventral thalamus, the midbrain raphe nuclei, and the locus coeruleus.

This combination of inputs to AGI from somatic sensory and frontal cortical fields, thalamic motor centers, and several other subcortical areas implies that AGl forms a subdivision of sensorimotor cortex that is important in centrally directed movements as well as those that are guided by somatic sensory feedback.

Introduction.S: The distinct cytoarchitecture of the rat somatic sensorimotor cortex and the large body of neurobiological data for this species make the rat extremely useful for studies of functional organization in cerebral neocortex.

The location, general organization, and cytoarchitectural correlates of the principal fields of the rat somatic sensorimotor cortex have been established with anatomical and electrophysiological techniques.
These studies have suggested that the sensorimotor cortex of rats contains several distinct cortical fields with precise functional correlates.
The classically defined first somatic sensory area (SI) lies within the parietal cortex and appears to have two functional subdivisions.
One subdivision contains the representation of cutaneous receptors and coincides with cytoarchitecturally distinct areas that are marked by their densely granular layer IV.
Each of these "granule cell a g gregates" contains the cortical representation of cutaneous inputs from a particular region of the body, such as the forelimb, hindlimb, or head (Welker, '71, '76).
Surrounding this granular field is a second subdivision of SI, termed the dysgranular field of SI, because it has a relatively thin layer IV (Donoghue and Wise, '82).
In this field neurons respond poorly to light tactile stimuli of the body surface, at least during barbiturate anesthesia (Welker, '76).
The second somatic sensory area (SII) is located in the parietal cortex lateral to SI and also contains a somatotopically organized cutaneous map (Welker and Sinha, '72).
Both SI and SII appear to receive their cutaneous input from connections with the ventrobasal complex of the thalamus (Killackey and Leshin, '75; Wise and Jones, '78).

The primary motor cortex (MI), identified as the region of the cortex where intracortical stimulation produces movements at the lowest thresholds (Hall and Lindholm, '74; Sanderson et al., %l), occupies two cytoarchitectonic fields (Donoghue and Wise, '82).
The bulk of MI coincides with a distinct frontal agranular area called the lateral agranular field (AGJ.
This part of MI contains the head, trunk, and part of the forelimb representation.
The remainder of MI is contained in the rostral part of the granular parietal cortex.
This part of MI overlaps with the SI cortex and contains the representation of the hindlimb and part of the forelimb (Hall and Lindholm, '74).

Neurons in the overlapping MI-SI area, as in the remaining parts of the granular cortex, are activated by light tactile stimulation (Welker, '76), and, in at least the region of the hindlimb representation, there is direct thalamic input from both the ventrobasal complex (VB) and ventrolateral complex (VL) (Donoghue et al., '79).
Thus, MI consists of two subdivisions in the rat.
The region of overlapping SI and MI cortex lies within granular cortex, receives cutaneous inputs relayed from VB, and is related to control of the hindlimb and forelimb.
The larger, non-overlapping part of MI corresponds to the lateral agranular field (AGl) and appears to be involved with movements of the head, trunk, and forelimb.

Despite the extensive knowledge of the functional organization of the granular fields of sensorimotor cortex, relatively little is known about the intracortical connectivity or the subcortical relations of the agranular part of MI.

The completion of baseline studies to establish a precise localization of MI in the rat (Hall and Lindholm, '74; Donoghue and Wise, '82) now permits a detailed analysis of the functional organization of MI and the entire sensorimotor cortex in this species.

In the present study, retrograde axonal tracers were injected into AG1 in order to identify the various sources of input that might regulate, influence, or control the intrinsic and output neurons of this part of MI.
The results show that AGI receives input from somatic sensory and frontal cortical areas, at least four thalamic nuclei, and basal forebrain and brainstem cell groups.
This diverse combination of inputs from sensory and motor control centers suggests that AGl has a role in the generation and guidance of movement in the rat.

Methods.S: METHODS

A single injection of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) was made in the frontal or parietal cortex of 16 albino rats (175-225 gm) during ketamine anesthesia (150 mglkg, supplemented as needed with doses of 5-10 mg, i.p.).
Wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to HRP (WGA-HRP, Sigma) was injected in the same cortical region of 17 additional rats.
In five animals the injection site was localized to the MI cortex by microstimulation mapping with a tungsten microelectrode (1-3 MQ at 1 kHz).
The cortex was stimulated through this electrode at a depth of 1.5-1.8 mm below the surface, by using currents of 5-100 pA (333 Hz, 200 psec pulses, 30-msec train) at three or four different sites.
Few penetrations were made in order to avoid extensive damage to the cortex.
In all other cases injections were placed under visual guidance, with the map of Hall and Lindholm ('74) as reference.
This method provides only a rough guide to the location of cytoarchitectonic fields.
Injections were aimed at AGl, medial agranular field (AG,), or the parietal cortex so that the pattern of connectivity of AG1 could be compared with the surrounding fields.

HRP (30% weightivolume) or WGA-HRP (4%), dissolved in TRIS buffer (pH 7.6) plus 0.9% NaCl, was deposited iontophoretically through glass micropipettes having tips of 15-50 p, by using currents of 1-10 pA for 1-30 minutes.
Various parameters of injection time and current were employed in an effort to make restricted injections that labeled many neurons.
The injection pipette was left in place for 5-15 minutes before it was removed.

Following a 2or 3-day post-injection survival the rats were perfused with 0.9% NaCl followed by 1 liter of a solution containing 2% paraformaldehyde and 1.5% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
In 17 animals the brains were stored for 2-3 hours in the same fixative after perfusion, then transferred to phosphate buffer.
The next day these brains were cut on a vibratome.
For the remaining 16 animals, perfusion with the same type of fixative described above was followed by perfusion with 500 ml of 10% sucrose in the aldehyde fixative.
These brains were stored overnight in 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer and then sectioned on a freezing microtome.
All brains were cut at 50 pm in the frontal plane.

One series of sections was treated with the chromagen tetramethyl benzidine (TMB) according to the procedure of Mesulam ('78) and a second series was treated with diaminobenzidine (DAB) by the method of LaVail et al. ('73).
Each series was composed of one-quarter of the sections and each section in a series was separated from the next by 150 pm.
TMB reacted sections were air dried after mounting and cleared in xylene.
These sections were not counterstained or dehydrated in alcohols, in order to prevent loss of TMB reaction product.
Sections treated with DAB were counterstained with thionin, dehydrated, and cleared in xylene.
The location of injection sites and peroxidase-labeled cells was charted on X26 projection drawings of selected unstained, TMB-reacted sections with the aid of a microscope and drawing tube.
All chartings were taken from the TMB-reacted tissue because cell labeling was more pronounced and because a greater number of cells were labeled with this method.
DAB-reacted sections were used mainly to localize the center of the injection.
Cytoarchitectonic boundaries were placed on each drawing by projecting an adjacent Nissl-stained, DAB incubated section onto the charting.
The two adjacent sections were aligned on blood vessels and surface landmarks.
The subdivisions of somatic sensorimotor cortex were labeled according to the description of Donoghue and Wise ( 82) and Welker ( 71; see also Zilles et al., 80).
Thalamic parcellation followed the descriptions of Donoghue et d. ( 79) and Herkenham ( 79).

Results.S: RESULTS
Cortical areas and injection sites
The principal cytoarchitectonic fields of sensorimotor cortex consist of the medial and lateral agranular fields of the frontal cortex and the granular and dysgranular fields of parietal cortex .
Aspects of the cytoarchitecture of these areas can be seen in Figures 1 and 4 and a surface reconstruction of the relative locations of these fields is shown in Figure 2.
Briefly , AGI is distinguished by its relatively indistinct lamination compared to surrounding fields .
The medial agranular field ( AG , ) is marked by a pale band in layer 111, while the granular SI cortex can be discerned by its well - developed layer IV , which is absent in the frontal cortex .
The dysgranular part of SI has a thinner , less distinct layer IV and surrounds the granular cortex ( Fig . 2 ) .
A full description of these areas is presented in Donoghue and Wise ( 82).
Descriptions of the cytoarchitecture of other frontal and insular fields can be found in Krettek and Price ( 77a ) , and their nomenclature for these fields is used in the present study .
Injections of HRP or WGA - HRP were contained within single fields or involved multiple fields .
In five cases the entire injection, as seen in TMB-reacted sections, was confined to AGI.
Nineteen other injections were centered in AGl but spread into AG,, the granular cortex, or both areas.
Five injections included AG, and spread into frontal fields other than AG1 .
Four injections involved only the granular and dysgranular fields of SI cortex .
The appearance of injection sites of HRP alone was quite different than those with WGA - HRP .
Large HRP injections had a dense center with a lighter halo that consisted of granular reaction product , labeled neurons , and fibers .
Small injections of HRP ( with dense cores less than 500 pm ) often appeared to consist only of densely labeled cells and axons , much like the halo of large injections .
Injections of WGA - HRP consisted almost entirely of a dense , well - demarcated core , as shown by the DAB method in Figure 1.
The TMB method produced a similar, slightly larger injection site (compare Fig. 1 with the illustration of the same injection in an adjacent TMB reacted section in Fig. 7B).
Attempts at making very small injections of WGA - HRP by using low currents ( 1 PA ) for short times ( 1 - 3 minutes ) produced injections larger than expected with HRP alone .
Even though these WGA - HRP injection sites were 200 - 500 pm in diameter they often produced few or no labeled cells .
Longer injection times (5-30 minutes) and higher currents (2-10 PA) produced injections as shown in Figure 1.
These injections were often no more than two or three times larger than the smallest WGAHRP injections , but these injections usually labeled large numbers of neurons .
Since boundaries of WGA - HRP injections are distinct it was possible to make large injections that were relatively restricted to AG1 with this tracer .
These large but restricted injections allowed some degree of confidence that all of the inputs to AGl were labeled.
In contrast , the halo of large injections of HRP without lectin always encompassed two or more cortical areas .

In some cases the pattern of labeling produced by these injections indicated that retrograde transport occurred from the halo , because , for example , labeled neurons were present in thalamic nuclei throught to project to a cortical field included only in the injection halo ( see Results ) .
Small injections of HRP alone labeled only a relatively small number of neurons but were more effective in producing cell labeling compared to similar - sized injections of WGA - HRP .
Thus , cases with very small injections of HRP that were clearly restricted to one cortical field were used to confirm the projections seen with large injections of HRP or WGAHRP .
Changing survival time from 2 to 3 days had no apparent effect on labeling patterns.
Afferent connections of AG,

TTE.S: The pattern of afferent connections of AGl will be illustrated from chartings of four representative cases : a large injection of WGA - HRP placed rostrally in AG1 near AGm ( PM 17, Fig . 3 ) , a small injection of HRP in AGI ( PM 3, Fig . 5 ) , a large injection of WGA - HRP in the caudal part of AG1 near SI ( PM 31, Fig . 7 ) , and a large injection of WGA - HRP in the frontal pole , rostral to AG1 ( PM 34, Fig . 8 ) .

The approximate size of each injection site, seen in TMB-reacted material, and its relative location with respect to cytoarchitectonic boundaries is reconstructed on a standard view of the neocortex in Figure 2.
The approximate level of each section that is illustrated in the subsequent figures is also indicated in this figure .
Injections of either HRP or WGA - HRP into AG1 label cells in the ipsilateral and contralateral cortex , the thalamus , the basal telencephalon , the midbrain , and the locus coeruleus .
An example of the pattern of labeling when a large injection of WGA - HRP is made in the rostral part of AGl is shown in Figure 3.

The dense part of this injection is largely confined to AGI but a small amount of dark reaction product, as well as densely labeled axons and cells (Fig. 5, hatching) around the injection lies within AG, (Fig. 3B).
The region of dense label and halo seen in an adjacent DAB - reacted section coincides roughly in size with the entire dark area seen in TMB - reacted sections .
Subsequent to this and five other cases with similar injections of WGA - HRP in AGI , labeled cells are located ipsilaterally in AG , and in the parietal cortex .
Labeling is present in layers I11 and V of AG , rostral and medial to the AGI ( Fig . 3A , C ) .
In the parietal cortex most of the labeled cells are situated in the dysgranular field of SI ( Figs . 3D , E , 4 ) .
Here , they are most numerous in layer 11, the upper three - quarters of layer 111, the upper part of layer V ( layer Va ) , and in the deepest part of layer VI ( Fig . 4 ) .
A few labeled cells are found in other layers of the dysgranular region , but the deep part of layer V and the bulk of layer VI are largely devoid of labeled cells .

Injections in AGI also label cells in the densely granular part of SI , but this field has many fewer labeled cells and a more restricted laminar distribution compared to the dysgranular area of SI ( Fig . 3D - G ) .

In the granular field labeled cells are mainly contained in a compact band in layer Va , and usually only few cells are present in layer 111, except near the edges of granule cell aggregates where a greater number of labeled cells is commonly present ( Fig . 3C ) .
The same band of labeled cells that is found in the deep part of layer VI in the dysgranular area is also found in the granular cortex .
This deep layer VI band is generally found below labeled cells in layer V and is more pronounced in the medial parts of SI , where the forelimb and hindlimb are represented .
In all cases only a few layer VI cells are labeled in the region of the trigeminal representation ( Fig . 3E , F ) .
This negative result may have been a consequence of a failure to make large enough injections in the appropriate subdivision of AG1.
Labeled cells are also present in the area of the second somatic sensory cortex ( SII ) in the same laminar arrangement as in the dysgranular cortex ( Fig . 3E - G ) .
Three cases with injections of HRP alone that had dense cores similar in location and size to PM 17 resulted in approximately the same cortical labeling pattern .
However , the extensive spread of the halo in these cases made it difficult to delineate the site of HRP uptake .

Subsequent to large injections into AG1 a few labeled cells are present in layers I11 and V of the ventral orbital area ( Fig . 3A ) , as defined by Krettek and Price ( ' 77a ) ; at the juncture between the caudal part of AG , and the retrosplenial cortex ( Fig . 3F ) ; near the border of parietal and occipital cortex ( Fig . 3H , I ) ; and along the rhinal fissure ( Fig . 3G ) .
These areas contain labeled neurons after injections near the medial border of AG1 that spread into AG,, suggesting that they mainly project to AG, and not AGl.
As will be shown below , injections clearly confined to AGI do not label cortical neurons outside of AG , , SI , or SII .
Contralaterally , a large number of labeled cells is present in all layers of AGl , except for the deeper two - thirds of layer VI ( Figs . 3B , 7B ) .
Injections that spread into AG , , or along the AGrAG border , label cells contralaterally in layers I11 and Va of SI ( Fig . 3C ) and the ventral orbital cortex ( Fig . 3A ) .

In the thalamus most of the cells labeled by AGl injections are located in the ventrolateral complex ( VL ) , the ventromedial nucleus ( VM ) , the central lateral ( CL ) and paracentral intralaminar nuclei , and the posterior medial nucleus ( POm ) .
A few cells are also found in the parafascicular nucleus ( Pf ) , lateral nuclear group ( L ) , the mediodorsal nucleus ( MD ) , and the central medial nucleus of the midline group ( Fig . 3G , H ) .

By comparing cases with greater or lesser involvement of AG , in the injection , it became evident that the number of labeled cells in MD , Pf , and the midline nuclei depends on the extent of spread of the injection into AG , .
The more the injection spreads into AG , the greater the labeling in these thalamic nuclei .
Large injections well away from the AG , - AGI boundary , or small injections within AGl which do not spread into AG , do not label cells in MD ( see below ) .
Large injections of WGA - HRP as in case PM 17 densely label many cells in the basal part of the telencephalon and in the globus pallidus ( Figs . 3E , F , 7E , F ) .
Similarly large injections of HRP alone also label neurons in these areas , but fewer neurons are labeled and the labeling of individual neurons is less dense .

Labeled neurons in this basal forebrain region have medium to large fusiform or spindleshaped somata and may be widely separated from each other or may occur in clusters of two to four neurons ( Fig . 6B ) .
A few labeled cells similar in morphology to these basal forebrain neurons are found in the preoptic area , in the region of the mammillary bodies , and in Forel 's fields ( Fig . 3G - I ) .
In the brainstem labeled cells are present ipsilaterally in the midbrain periaqueductal gray , the nucleus raphe magnus , and locus coeruleus ( Fig . 6A ) .
Smaller injections ( 300 - 500 pn ) of HRP into AG1 produce a pattern of labeling similar to that of larger injections , with two expected differences .

First , fewer labeled cells are found in each of the areas that are labeled by large injections and second , areas that contain a comparatively small number of neurons subsequent to large injections ( such as the locus coeruleus ) may not contain labeled cells .
An example of one of three cases that has a very small injection of HRP ( without lectin ) completely restricted to AG1 is shown in Figure 5.
Microstimulation in this rostral part of AGl at 15 pA produced extension of the forelimb digits.
The location of this injection and the microstimulation effect suggests that it involves the MI rostral forelimb zone recently described by Neafsey and Sievert ('82).
In this case the HRP injection involved all layers except the deeper one - half of layer VI .

Corticocortical cells are again found mainly in the dysgranular fields and SII ipsilaterally ( Fig . 5 ) , but unlike large AG1 injections , the bands of labeled cells in layers V and VI of SI are not evident .
The sparse labeling in layers V and VI could indicate that these SI neurons project to the deeper layers of AG1, since they are labeled mainly with large injections that spread into the deep layers .
Alternatively , the presence of labeling in the deep layers could depend on the quantity of HRP injected .
With small AGI injections thalamic labeling is confined to VL, VM, C1, and POm (Fig. 5F-H).
In all cases with small injections , labeling in the midbrain , locus coeruleus , and ventral diencephalic and basal forebrain regions is sparse or absent .
Injections of HRP or WGA - HRP placed more caudally in AGl near the SI cortex confirm the principal connections of this field .

Case PM 31 ( Fig . 7 ) illustrates the labeling following an injection that is largely within the caudolateral part of AGl but also involves to a small extent the medial edge of the granular cortex , where the forelimb is represented in SI .
In the cortex the majority of labeled cells are contained in SI , SII , and AG , .
Thus , labeled cells are present in each of these three cortical fields following any injection that involves AGl .

The absence of labeling in perirhinal , retrosplenial , orbital , or posterior parietal fields that is present following large , rostrally and medially placed injections suggests that these frontal fields are labeled as a result of spread of the injection zone into AG , or other frontal fields .
The same thalamic nuclei are labeled in this case as with other injections of AG1, except for a small number of cells in VB .
Whenever the granular cortex is involved in an injection , labeled cells are found in VB , but VB is never labeled from injections restricted to agranular cortex .
In some cases labeled cells are found in VB when the halo from the HRP injection ( DAB substrate ) spreads into SI .
None of the caudal AGl injections labels cells in MD .
Differences in the location of labeled cells in various thalamic nuclei indicate that there is a topographic organization of input to AG1.
Injections placed more caudally in AGl tend to label cells in the rostrolateral part of VL , while more rostral injections label cells in the more caudomedial portions of VL .

Results.S: However, there appears to be substantial overlap of the parts of VL labeled by injections in different parts of AG1.
This general pattern of medial to rostral and lateral to caudal appears to be true for the projections of POm and the intralaminar nuclei to AGl .
Injections rostral to AGI

TTE.S: Five injections of HRP were centered in the frontal cortex rostral to AGl , both to compare the pattern of labeling from these cortical fields with that following AG1 injections and to control for labeling of pathways that occur when AG1 injections spread into AG , .
When WGA-HRP or HRP injections are confined to fields rostral to AGl a markedly different pattern of labeling results.
The most striking differences are first , the general lack of labeling in SI cortex , and second , the large number of labeled areas in the cortex and thalamus .
An example of the labeling from a large injection in the frontal pole of the neocortex is shown in Figure 8.
This injection involves the rostromedial part of AG , as well as the medially adjacent prelimbic field .

Within the cortex many labeled cells are found in the rostralmost parts of the cerebral cortex that surround the frontal pole ( Fig . 8A ) , in the agranular insular and adjacent parts of the perirhinal cortex ( Fig . 8B - E ) , and in AG , caudal to the injection site ( Fig . 8B ) .

All injections that spread into the frontal cortex medial to AG , also label cells in the pyramidal cell layer of the hippocampus , which confirms a previous report of a projection from Ammon 's horn to limbic cortex in the rat ( Swanson , ' 81 ) .
Large injections rostral to AG1 label a small number of cells in AGl , SII , and the posterior parietal cortex ( Fig . 8D ) .
These cells are mainly found in layers V ( a and b ) and VI ( Fig . 8D ) , except in SII where labeled cells are found in all layers except I and IV .

Each injection in AG , that clearly does not involve AG1 labels only a few cells in the SI cortex , which contrasts dramatically with the large numbers of cells in SI that are seen following injections of similar size in AG1.
The few cells labeled in SI are not restricted to either the granular or dysgranular regions and are usually in layer Va or the deep part of layer VI .

Commissural cells marked by these frontal injections are present in all layers of the contralateral homotopic area of cortex and are also present in orbital fields , caudal AG , , and in the agranular insular cortex .
Another small group of cells is present caudally along the rhinal fissure , immediately adjacent to the pyriform cortex ( Fig . 8F arrow ) .
Injections of the frontal cortex rostral to AG1 label numerous subcortical areas including the amygdala and a number of thalamic nuclei .
The basolateral nucleus of the amygdala contains labeled neurons after all injections that spread into the prelimbic and infralimbic cortical fields that lie medial to AG , .
In an earlier study , Krettek and Price ( ' 77b ) demonstrated projections from the amygdala to these cortical fields using anterograde transport techniques .
Following any injection that includes AG , or medially adjacent fields , there are numerous labeled neurons in the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus .

Labeled cells are also present in many other thalamic nuclei including VL , VM , and several intralaminar ( mainly the central lateral , paracentral , and parafascicular nuclei ) and midline thalamic nuclei .

The large number of thalamic nuclei labeled by these injections may reflect convergence of thalamocortical inputs or could be a consequence of large injections that involve many different , smaller cortical fields .
Common to all injections into frontal or parietal cortex , parts of the basal forebrain , globus pallidus , hypothalamus , and Forel 's fields contain labeled cells .

Results.S: However, there appear to be more labeled cells in each of these regions following injections that involve the cortex rostral to AG1, compared to injections of AG1 alone.
The rostral frontal cortex also appears to receive bilateral input from the region of the mammillary bodies (Fig. 8F).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

These retrograde transport experiments show that the lateral agranular field of the rat motor cortex receives a variety of inputs from ipsilateral and contralateral cortical areas, several thalamic nuclei, the basal forebrain region, and at least two brainstem regions.

The specific sources of input to AGl and the differences in the connections of surrounding cortical fields support our conclusion that AG1 is a distinct cortical field that coincides with all of the MI cortex, except for the region of overlap with SI (Donoghue and Wise, '82).
The nature of the inputs to AGl suggests that this cortical area has an important role in sensorimotor control in the rat.
Methodological considerations
The conclusions of this study are based on experiments employing retrograde transport techniques.
The major problem in the interpretation of results from such studies is the determination of the effective zone of transport.
WGA-HRP was used in addition to unconjugated HRP, because use of WGA-HRP appears to result in a sharply defined injection zone.
However, with either type of HRP it is impossible to determine the exact zone of transport by examination of the injection site itself.
For this reason, injections were made in various parts of AG1, in the surrounding fields, and along boundaries.

Comparisons of the differences in the pattern of labeling from injections that involve different cytoarchitectonic fields allow a more secure conclusion that a particular projection is limited to one or another field.
Nevertheless, it cannot be definitively stated with this method that certain inputs precisely follow cytoarchitectonic boundaries.
Cortical connections of AGI
The major ipsilateral cortical inputs to AG1 arise from SI, SII, and AG,.
Within SI the majority of cells that project to AGl are found in a distinct cytoarchitectonic area, the dysgranular field.
This projection arises from supragranular layers and from parts of layer V and VI.

The dysgranular field appears to be a separate subdivision of SI because, during barbiturate anesthesia, cells in this area respond poorly to cutaneous stimuli, while those in the adjacent granular zones respond well (Welker, '76).
This difference in response properties of these two parts of SI also correlates with a difference in thalamic connectivity.

The dysgranular cortex apparently does not receive input from VB (Killackey and Leshin, '75; Wise and Jones, '78), but instead, its main thalamic input appears to arise from POm (Herkenham, '80; Lin and Chapin, '81).
Akers and Killackey ('78) have shown that there are direct projections from the granule cell region to the dysgranular cortex in the rat.
Thus, the dysgranular cortex appears to form a link between the granular cortex and AGI.
There is also a direct projection from the granular field of SI to AGl that arises almost entirely from layer Va and the deepest part of layer VI.
The projection from layer Va of SI to the "motor cortex" has been previously reported by Ivy and Killackey ('82).
The labeling of the deep part of layer VI after large AGI injections could be a result of uptake from fibers that pass through the deep part of AGI to more rostral areas.
However, the sparse labeling in SI following even very large injections rostral to AGI leads to the conclusion that the main cortical target of the deep layer VI cells in SI is AGI.
In addition to intracortical connections, it is possible that some of the AGlprojecting neurons in the infragranular layers have branched projections to subcortical structures.
A large number of cells in layer Va project to the striatum (Wise and Jones, '77; Hedreen, '77) and layer VI is a major source of corticothalamic projections (Wise and Jones, '77).
Since cells projecting to AGI are found in both of these layers, motor cortex could receive a copy of some of the same output from SI cortex as the neostriatum and thalamus.
These speculations require testing with appropriate anatomical or electrophysiological methods.
Other pathways appear to be segregated so that collateralized projections are not possible.
For example, throughout parietal cortex there are very few cells in the deeper part of layer V that project to AG1, but many of these neurons project to the brainstem or spinal cord.
Thus, at least part of the major descending output of SI is not directly transferred to AGl.
This is consistent with the finding that commissural and corticospinal cells are completely separate in the rat (Catsman-Berrevoets et al., '80).
Another cortical input to AGI arises from SII.

Since SII is a target of VB (Wise and Jones, '78) and SII neurons are responsive to cutaneous inputs (Welker and Sinha, '78), this area is potentially another cortical route for somatic sensory input to reach AG1.
A third source of cortical input to AGl is the medial agranular cortex.
This input originates in both hemispheres but is strongest ipsilaterally.

AG, is considered to be separate from AGI and not part of MI because it has different cytoarchitecture and microstimulation thresholds (Donoghue and Wise, '82), and because MD projects to AG, and not to AG1.

However, consistent with the idea of a motor function for this field, AG, receives input from VL, contains corticospinal neurons (Wise et al., '79; Donoghue and Wise, '82), and projects to MI cortex (i.e., AGI).
Together, these functions seem to be sufficient to conclude that AG, is part of the sensorimotor cortex but is also distinct from AGI and, therefore, MI.

The similarity of position, cytoarchitecture, and connectivity of the supplementary motor cortex (MII) of primates to AG, suggests that there is an MI1 in the rat that occupies part or perhaps all of AG,.
Without further information, however, any attempt to infer homology to any field of primate sensorimotor cortex is tenuous.
Alternatively, it is possible that AG, is a uniquely specialized field or group of fields of the rat sensorimotor cortex.
Orbital areas of frontal cortex, perirhinal cortex, posterior parietal cortex, and retrosplenial cortex appear to project to AG, but not to AGI.
This conclusion is supported by two observations.
First, injections that involve AG,, but do not include AGl, label cells in these cortical areas.
Second, very large injections in the caudal or lateral parts of AGI do not label cells in any cortical area outside of AG,, SI, and SII.

The difficulty in making injections of HRP that are sufficiently large to label all inputs to an area without involving an adjacent area makes it possible, however, that there are subdivisions of AG1near AG, that receive input from areas of cortex outside of SI, SII, and AG,.
Except for this possibility, AG, appears to be the major cortical route between frontal and limbic cortical areas and MI cortex.
The remarkable density of commissural connections of AGI suggests that there is a massive interchange of information from the motor cortex of one hemisphere to the other.
A similar commissural pattern is also seen in the MI cortex of monkeys (Zant and Strick, '78).
A few cells are labeled in the contralateral SI cortex subsequent to large injections in the rostral part of AGI near the border of AG,.

Since the contralateral SI does not contain labeled cells after large injections of AG, (not involving AGl), it seems likely that a few cells in SI may project directly to AGI or near the border of AGI and AG,.
Whether these fibers terminate within AG1 or AG, or both would require a number of well-localized HRP injections in these areas, or injection of an anterograde tracer in SI.
The pattern of intracortical connectivity of the sensorimotor fields of the rat has many similarities to that of the squirrel and macaque monkeys.
As in the rat, the region of SI activated by cutaneous input (area 3b) projects to another subdivision of SI (area 2), which in turn projects densely to MI (Jones et al., '78).
In this respect the dysgranular field of SI is like area 2 in these monkeys.
However, it is possible that the dysgranular field represents a specialized cortical field not present in the monkey or that it is an amalgamation of several parietal fields found in other species.
Thalamic connections of AGI

On the basis of numbers of labeled neurons, the principal thalamic input to AG1 arises from VL. which is the target of ascending fibers from the globus pallidus (Severin et al., '76; Carter and Fibiger, '77) and the cerebellum (Faull and Carman, '78).
However, AGI cannot be defined as the sole target of VL, since VL projects to cytoarchitectonic fields outside of AG1, including AG,.

The pattern of connections of VL with a large part of frontal agranular cortex described here is in substantial agreement with earlier studies (Jones and Leavitt, '74; Krettek and Price, '77a; Herkenham, '80).
However, precise comparison of data from these studies with the present one is difficult because the cytoarchitectonic correlates of MI have been only recently established.
It would be of interest to show that AG, and AGI receive inputs from separate subdivisions of VL.

However, a strong case cannot yet be made for subdividing VL into separate nuclei in the rat, at least based on cytoarchitecture or on our present knowledge of the termination of fibers from the cerebellum and the globus pallidus in this nuclear region.
Although AG, and AG1 both receive VL input, of these two, only AG, receives fibers from MD, as shown in the present experiments.
Several other studies have demonstrated projections from MD to an area that includes AG,, but does not include AG1 (Leonard, '69; Domesick, '72; Beckstead, '76; Krettek and Price, '77a).
Thus, the projection from MD serves to differentiate AG, from AGI and this major connectional difference supports our speculation that these cortical areas have separate functions.

Although AG1 can be distinguished from surrounding somatic sensorimotor fields on the basis of different thalamic inputs, AGl shares a number of thalamic inputs with SI and with AG,, in addition to its thalamic input from VL.

All three of these fields receive input from the central lateral nucleus (Jones and Leavitt, '74; Wise and Jones, '78; Donoghue et al., '79) and the ventromedial nucleus (Leonard, '69; Herkenham, '79).
In addition, POm appears to project to the entire sensorimotor cortex (Wise and Jones, '78; Donoghue et al., '79; Herkenham, '80).
Pf projects to AGm and may also project to AG1 because a few cells are labeled in Pf with large injections in AGl.
Herkenham ('80) also identified a projection from Pf to the deep layers of "the motor area," which probably includes AG1.
The lack of labeling in Pf with small HRP injections may be a result of lack of spread of the tracer to layer VI in these cases.
Other subcortical inputs to AGl
Neurons are labeled in the basal telencephalon, the hypothalamus, and the ventral thalamic region after HRP injection in any part of the frontal or parietal cortex.

It has been suggested that neurons in each of these telencephalic and diencephalic areas form part of a cholinergic system that projects to all areas of cerebral cortex in the rat and in other species (Divac, '75; Kievitt and Kuypers, '75; Mesulam and Van Hoesen, '76).
Similarly, the midbrain raphe nuclei and the locus coeruleus project widely to all cortical areas.

The projection from the raphe nuclei probably provides a serotonergic input (Lidov et al., '80) and the locus coeruleus provides a noradrenergic input to AGl (Freedman et al., '75; Lindvall et al., '78; Morrison et al., '78).
Each of these systems with widespread cortical projections are thought to have a modulatory influence on the general level of neuronal activity.

Norepinephrine, for example, has been suggested to enhance the response of neurons to afferent inputs in the cortex while having little or no direct effect on the neuronal discharge by itself (Waterhouse et al., '81).
The role of AG1 as a cortical field

The combination of inputs from several sensory and motor areas suggests that AG1 is a cortical field that plays an important role in the control of movements guided by sensory feedback as well as in the execution of centrally programmed movements.

A role in the sensory guidance of movements would require a route for rapid peripheral sensory feedback to AG1 and there appear to be a number of pathways for somatic sensory information to reach AGl.
The dysgranular field could serve to transfer processed sensory information from the granular field of SI to AGl.

The dysgranular field could also transfer input from deep (joint, muscle spindle) receptors to MI, since information from these sensory receptors appear to activate in the dYsgranular field (Chapin and Woodward, '82)The smaller direct projection from the granular field to AGl may provide a parallel route for cutaneous information to reach MI.

The restricted laminar origin of this projection suggests that only a specific type of information is transferred from the granular field of SI to AG~. s11 is another possible direct cortical Source of cutaneous input to MI in the rat.
Thalamic pathways for somatic sensory input to AG1 are less evident.
The principal thalamic source of somatic sensory information, VB, does not project to AG1.

However, peripheral sensory input may reach AGl through VL or C1, which appear to be targets of ascending spinothalamic pathways, or through POm, which receives some dorsal column and spinal input in the rat (Lund and Webster, '67a,b; McAllister and Wells, '81).
In addition to somatic sensory inputs, AG1 is also a major target of areas that are likely to be involved in the generation and execution of central motor programs.
The major cortical input to AGl, outside of SI and SII, is AG,.

This field appears to form a route for diverse cortical areas, such as the posterior parietal cortex and the prelimbic field, as well as juxtallocortical (perirhinal) areas, to influence to the motor cortex.
Subcortical motor structures are connected to AGl largely through abundant thalamic connections.
Pallidal and cerebellar information reaches AG1 through VL (Severin et al., '76; Carter and Fibiger, '77; Faull and Carman, '78).
It is not yet clear whether basal ganglia and cerebellar routes are relayed through separate parts of VL or whether these pathways are kept separate in cortex.
Output from the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra, another subcortical structure with a role in motor control, reaches MI through VM.
This thalamic nucleus projects densely to layer I throughout the rostral part of the cortex (Herkenham, '79).
As suggested by Herkenham ('79) this projection could provide another input that affects the general level of cortical activity.
Other features of the rat MI suggest that it has an important role in motor control, particularly for the forelimb.
Elger et al. ('77) have reported that corticospinal neurons in the rat may monosynaptically influence motor neurons for the forelimb, but not for the hindlimb (Janzen et al., '77).

Cortical lesions involving AG1 have been shown to alter the force output of the forelimb (Price and Fowler, '81) and to disrupt skilled forelimb movements in the rat (Castro, '72), suggesting a role for MI in the rat that is not unlike that of the macaque monkey (Evarts, '68; Lawrence and Kuypers, '68).

The availability of a detailed description of MI in the rat by cytoarchitecture, microstimulation, and connectivity provides a background for future studies to identify the role of MI neurons and their various inputs in generating, modulating, and shaping cortical output and finally, movement.
